法規內容.條文內容: These Regulations have been established pursuant to Article 25 of the Seafarer Act.

Foreign employers shall apply to employ seafarers from the Republic of China (R.O.C.) in accordance with the provisions established herein.
Foreign employers mentioned herein refer to employers from nations that have a good relationship with the R.O.C.

In order to manage the employment of R.O.C. seafarers by foreign employers and provide employed seafarers with better services, the Maritime Administration has approved the creation of "The Committee for R.O.C. Seafarers Employed by Foreign Employers" (hereinafter referred to as the Committee) to offer aid with regard to processing employment procedures and integrating and providing consultation services to settle disputes between employers and employees, as well as to assume responsibilities related to the depository and utilization of the relief fund financed for seafarers employed by foreign employers.
Falling under the supervision of the Maritime Administration, the Committee is made up of representatives designated by the Master Mariners Association, National Chinese Seamen’s Union, R.O.C. Vessel Carriers, R.O.C. Shipping Agency, and Maritime Administration.
The Committee shall have seven to fifteen members, among which one chairman, one deputy chairman, and one financial committee member shall be elected. These members’ positions shall be unpaid and have a term of service of three years. The chairman may be reappointed once when elected successively, while all other members may be reappointed when elected successively. General committee meetings shall be held quarterly and special meetings can be convened whenever necessary.
One or two members from the paragraph above shall be assigned by the Master Mariners Association; two to four members shall be assigned by the National Chinese Seamen’s Union; one or two shall be assigned by the R.O.C. Vessel Carriers; two to five shall be assigned by the R.O.C. Shipping Agency; and one or two shall be assigned by the Maritime Administration.
The relief fund created for seafarers employed by foreign employers shall be distributed to help settle disputes between employers and employees. The administrative guidelines for said fund shall be established by the Committee.
Any expenses of the Committee and related to the relief fund created for seafarers employed by foreign employers shall be assumed by foreign employers on a monthly basis according to the number of vessels and seafarers they have employed. The fund collection rate shall be established by the Committee and submitted to the Maritime Administration for approval.
The Committee may employ numerous short-term employees as it deems necessary to handle Committee affairs. The Committee’s establishment plan shall be submitted to the Maritime Administration for approval.

All foreign employers shall entrust their employment of R.O.C. seafarers to either a R.O.C. shipping carrier or a R.O.C. shipping agency as an agent for employment. Foreign employers are required to fill in the application form (see Attachment 1) and provide the following documentation to the Maritime Administration when applying for the appropriate permission:
1. A photocopy of the company’s license and its Chinese translation. (The photocopy of the company’s license can be substituted by a photocopy certified by a R.O.C. embassy, consulate, representative office or any other organization authorized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.)
2. Profile of the person-in-charge and the company’s business scope (see Attachment 2).
3. A photocopy of the Letter of Authorization certified by a R.O.C. embassy, consulate, representative office or any other organization authorized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (see Attachment 3).
4. A list of the vessels of the foreign employer (see Attachment 4).
5. A photocopy of the company license of agents.
Any change to the documents listed above shall be reported to the Maritime Administration for future reference.

Should business necessity require it, a foreign employer can send a representative to R.O.C. territory to help coordinate the employment of R.O.C. seafarers.
A foreign employer’s representative in the R.O.C. shall obtain approval from the Maritime Administration by also including a photocopy of his/her household registration or personal ID (affixed with a big and small company seal). Such representatives shall then register themselves with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) in accordance with Article 386 of the Company Act within two months after approval. Any foreign representative who fails to do so within the stipulated period may be subject to permit cancellation by the Maritime Administration.
Upon completing registration in accordance with the provision in the paragraph above, the representative shall submit a copy of the Letter of Permission issued by the MOEA and the Registration Form for the Representative of a Foreign Employer, as well as two copies of certified chop imprints, to the Maritime Administration for future reference.
The Maritime Administration shall send a copy of its approval regarding the dispatch of representative by a foreign vessel carrier to inform the MOEA, and shall also do the same in the case of cancelling or revoking such dispatch.
A foreign employer operating a total of five vessels or more or a total of 30,000 gross tonnage or more that has a representative approved by the Maritime Administration prior to the amendment made to these Regulations may be exempt from assigning another representative through the process above. Such a representative shall be permitted to continue his/her original task of employing seafarers.
If the total number or the total gross tonnage of vessels of the foreign employer mentioned in the previous paragraph decreases to the number or the tonnage established in the paragraph above, the foreign employer shall designate another agent for the employment of seafarers. Furthermore, the foreign vessel carrier shall have their ability to employ R.O.C. seafarers suspended until the new representative has been approved by the Maritime Administration.

A foreign employer’s representative in R.O.C. territory shall be a R.O.C. national or an overseas R.O.C. national possessing a foreign residence permit and R.O.C. domicile registration. No one with any of the following circumstances shall be designated as a representative, and approval shall be revoked if any such person has already been designated:
1. Any circumstance stipulated in the provisions established in Article 30 of the Company Act.
2. Any person who had been a representative, but had permission revoked within the last five years.

When entering into an employment contract on behalf of a foreign employer, the representative shall declare its agency’s intention within the employment contract and then affix said contract with the agency’s signature or seal.
When appropriate, the Maritime Administration may regulate the number of foreign employers and vessels of a representative’s agent.

R.O.C. seafarers can only be employed by foreign employers upon being registered with and permitted by the Maritime Administration by providing one copy of each of the following validated documents:
1. Particulars of Vessel (see Attachment 5).
2. Certificate of Vessel Nationality.
3. Classification Certificate.
4. The special agreement related to the employment of R.O.C. seafarers signed with the National Chinese Seamen’s Union or equivalent related documents certified by the Union.
The vessels registering to employ R.O.C. seafarers by foreign employers mentioned in the paragraph above shall be vessels of 1,600 gross tonnage or more those vessels under 1,600 gross tonnage shall apply specially to the Maritime Administration to employ R.O.C. seafarers.
The related documents mentioned in Item 4, Paragraph 1 herein may be replaced by documents that prove the payment of a security bond for the employment of ROC seafarers certified by the Committee. The method and amount of the aforementioned payment shall be established by the Committee and submitted to the Maritime Administration for approval.
Any foreign employer who hires R.O.C. seafarers shall obtain insurance for both its vessels and its seafarers.
All documents of the insurance mentioned in the paragraph above shall be sent to the Committee for approval at the same time as signing the special agreement related to the employment of R.O.C. seafarers, applying for certification, or paying the security bond; the same shall also be done in the case of any change is made to these insurance documents.

Foreign employer required permission in order to sign an employment contract when employing a R.O.C seafarer and shall submit the documents listed below to the Maritime Administration for future inspection and reference.
1. List of seafarer information.
2. Copy of seafarer employment contract.
3. Copy of membership of the Master Mariners Association or National Chinese Seamen’s Union.

A foreign employer who contracts R.O.C. seafarers shall put the seafarers to work on board a vessel within one month from the date of completing the employment procedures. During said period, no seafarer shall request to be transferred to another vessel of another foreign employer without the consent of the original foreign employer.
In the case that a foreign employer does not have the seafarers working on board a vessel within the aforementioned time period, said foreign employer is required to pay such seafarers a provisional monthly wage. Said wage shall be no less than half a basic wage per month as set forth in the contract and shall be paid starting from the first day of the month after the month in which the employment procedures had been completed.
If seafarers are still unassigned as of the first day of the fourth month, said seafarers shall be paid a provisional wage every month of at least two-thirds of the basic monthly wage set forth in the contract.
A foreign employer may cease payment of said provisional wage to a seafarer if the seafarer does not report to an assignment or refuses to be on board on the selected day upon being officially notified of the boarding in the period in which he agreed to be paid a provisional wage. Said seafarer shall then be required to return all provisional wages that he has received.
No seafarer may request to be transferred to another vessel of another foreign employer throughout the period in which he agrees to be paid a provisional wage unless said request is agreed upon by both parties, and the seafarer returns all provisional wages that he has already received.
A seafarer can request a transfer to another vessel of another foreign employer at any time provided that the original foreign employer fails to pay the provisional wage monthly as stipulated in the second paragraph of this Article. Such a foreign employer shall not claim for any compensation or detain any of the seafarer’s certificates but shall be required to pay all outstanding provisional wages.

Any foreign employer who would like to transfer an approved seafarer to another one of its vessels or to borrow a seafarer approved to be employed by another foreign employer shall first obtain the concerned seafarer’s consent and then re-sign the employment contract. Said new foreign employer shall submit the re-signed employment contract, the "Responsibility Transfer Report on Transferring Seafarers by Foreign Vessel Carriers" (see Attachment 6), and the list of seafarer information to the Maritime Administration within 15 days for future reference. If the foreign employer is the same before and after the transfer, the years of employment of the transferred seafarer stipulated in the contract shall not be interrupted.
No foreign employer shall lend the R.O.C. seafarers it has employed to any other foreign employer that has not been approved to employ R.O.C. seafarers to carry out seaman tasks or any other tasks.

The representative of a foreign employer shall create and submit the Monthly Report on the Number of Onboard and Onshore R.O.C. Seafarers (see Attachment 7) to the Maritime Administration for future reference every month before the tenth day of the following month.

In the case that a R.O.C. seafarer or a vessel on which the seafarer serves has an accident or experiences a significant event, the foreign employer or its representative shall immediately notify the Maritime Administration of such circumstance.

In the event that a seafarer leaves the vessel without permission in a foreign country, the foreign employer or its representative shall fill out and submit the Report on Seafarers Leaving Vessels in a Foreign Country without Permission (see Attachment 8) to the Maritime Administration for investigation and handling.

A foreign employer that hires R.O.C. seafarers shall not order such seafarers to violate R.O.C. laws or regulations or do anything that may possibly jeopardize national interests. Such an employer shall be required to return such seafarers to the R.O.C. when the R.O.C. government summons them for military service.

Any one of a foreign employer’s vessels that employs R.O.C. seafarers shall not sail to countries, areas, or ports that are restricted by the R.O.C. government unless previously reporting it to the Maritime Administration, which shall consult with relevant authorities and approve such sailing before it takes place.

Any matter not prescribed in these regulations regarding the rights and responsibilities of R.O.C. seafarers employed by a foreign employer shall be interpreted in accordance with the provisions established in the existing laws and ordinances of the R.O.C. and the specific employment contract.

When a foreign employer returns a R.O.C. seafarer to the R.O.C. and applies to cancel his/her registration, said employer shall submit a report detailing the reason for repatriation, as well as the dismissal or transfer to another subordinate vessel for service after the repatriation and a copy of the seafarer list to the Maritime Administration for approval to cancel registration.

The Maritime Administration may notify a foreign employer to replace its representative due to any of the following circumstances. Prior to replacing the representative, the Maritime Administration may suspend said foreign employer’s permission to employ R.O.C. seafarers.
1. The representative fails to start business within six months after the registration or shuts down the business for a period more than six months after starting business.
2. The representative has shut down the business or has been ordered to shut down the business as a penalty.
3. The representative’s right to represent a foreign employer with regard to hiring R.O.C. seafarers is suspended.
4. The person-in-charge of the representative has violated any of the provisions stipulated in Article 30 of the Company Act.
5. The representative has the permission to employ R.O.C. seafarers revoked or suspended.
Regarding Item 1 above, the foreign employer may apply for an extension of the permission to hire R.O.C. seafarers as long as it has a valid reason for the extension.

Any foreign employer or its representative that violates these regulations shall be punished pursuant to the Seafarer Act and other relevant laws and regulations, as well as be liable to suspension of applying for permission to hire or to accept the entrustment to hire R.O.C. seafarers for no less than three months but no more than two years.
Any foreign employer or its representative that constitutes a significant violation of the provisions prescribed herein shall be punished by the revocation of the ability to apply for permission to hire or to accept the entrustment to hire R.O.C. seafarers.

R.O.C. seafarers engaged to serve a vessel of a foreign employer who is penalized by revoking its permission to hire R.O.C. seafarers shall leave the vessel at the port that is most convenient for them to return to the port where they are employed. The foreign employer shall be responsible for returning all such seafarers to the port where they are employed.
R.O.C. seafarers engaged to serve a vessel of a foreign employer who is penalized by suspending its permission to hire R.O.C. seafarers may continue to serve said vessel until the term of employment expires if the seafarers choose to do so. However, the foreign employer shall be responsible for returning all such seafarers to the port where they are employed upon expiration of the employment contract.
These regulations shall take effect as of the day of promulgation; Article 3, which was amended and issued on August 10, 2015, shall take effect on April 27, 2016.
